title: consider this. _.has feature. dot notation.
body:
I feel compelled to at least ask this. I know you will probably scream and decline. Would you consider adding dot notation searching for _.has()? I know you might scream because if not implemented properly this could slow down performance. But often I need to check for multiple dimensions in objects and end up checking each property up the chain to ensure I don't end up with a error resulting from checking an undefined reference for a property.

Example usage: `_.has("user.session.id")`

Before you decline this at least consider it.
I've heard the argument for this and both sides have validity.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10934664/convert-string-in-dot-notation-to-get-the-object-reference

title: Lodash doesn't work in Browserify
The option for _.throttle to execute only on the trailing edge
body:
Sometimes one wants to have throttle only execute on the trailing edge of the period.

I believe the patch to achieve this is trivial:

``` javascript
  function throttle(func, wait, trailingOnly) {
    var args,
        result,
        thisArg,
        timeoutId,
        lastCalled = trailingOnly ? new Date : 0;
```

Just a suggestion :thought_balloon: Cheers. :beers:

title: Lodash vs Lodash.underscore
body:
I have what is probably a strange corner case, but I still wanted to bring it up as feedback and get your thoughts.

I created and maintain a widget library that my company uses in many different apps. One of those apps uses Backbone but the rest don't. After Lodash v1.0 was relased, Lodash became incompatible out of the box with Backbone, and that presented an interesting dilema for me.

I know Lodash has the Backbone and Underscore builds, and I know I can add specific functionality to those builds, but I'm encountering weirdness that's making me wonder if a complex custom build is worth it.

For example:

`lodash.underscore` doesn't support early exiting from `forEach` by returning `false`. The `forIn` and `forOwn` methods (which are not part of Underscore) do support it, but if I create the following custom build `lodash underscore plus="forIn,forOwn"` the `forIn` and `forOwn` methods now **do not** support early exiting.

I dug around in the source for a bit, and it makes sense why this happens in these cases (`indicatorObject` has changed), but now I'm wondering what else would be different as I start adding in Lodash methods to an Underscore build. I was originally under the impression that Lodash-specific methods would not be changed in custom builds, but clearly this is not always the case.

Basically, my question is to what degree are Lodash methods affected by being added to an Underscore build. Also to what degree can I add custom methods and still expect Backbone compatibility (if this information is even known). I imagine there are other people in my similar situation who are a little uneasy about maintaining a custom build that both supports Backbone but also allows for some of the other Lodash sweetness.

I'm not necessarily looking for a huge response. I'm mainly bringing up my situation so you can consider it. Also, if there's a plan for more documentation to be released on the differences between Underscore and Lodash as well as using Backbone with Underscore, that would be awesome!

Now that Lodash is no longer just a drop-in replacement, I think more details on the differences would be very helpful.

Thanks and keep up the great work!

title: `this` value is lost when iterating via forOwn (Lodash.underscore)
body:
Since v1.1.0, it seems that Lodash created a bug when passing an iteration from `forEach` to `forOwn`.

I only tested it with the Lodash.underscore so I can't say if it's limited to this build in particular.

I've been able to fix the bug in the underscore build by changing [line 745](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/master/dist/lodash.underscore.js#L745)  by this one using `call` to keep the this value:

``` javascript
if (callback.call(thisArg, iterable[index], index, collection) === indicatorObject) return result;
```

I'd send a pull request, but I'm not sure how this all work with the build and the system. I hope this helps a little.

title: Deep Find
body:
I am looking for a key ("dateCreated") someplace in a huge object. _.find only seems to work up to one nested level deep. and it only returns the first instance. I'd like to have a function that works similar to the way xpath did returning an array of references to all objects containing that key within the collection.
```js
_.find({ 'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': {'d':{'e':7}}}, "d"); // Object {d: Object}
_.find({ 'a': 1, 'b': 2, 'c': {'d':{'e':7}}}, "e"); // undefined
_.find({ 'aa': 1, 'bb': 2, 'cc': {'d':{'x':9}}, dd:{'d':{'y':9}}}, 'd'); // Object {d: Object} d: Object x: 9
```
1) it seems strange that _.find found something one level deep (i.e o.c.d) but couldn't find something two levels deep (i.e. `o.c.d.e`) 
2) how do i find additional instances of 'd' (i.e. `cc.d`, `dd.d`...)
OR can i get an array instead (e.g. `[cc.d, dd.d]`)

I ran a quick test against 1.1.0
http://codepen.io/anon/pen/bnqyh

As usual big props for an awesome library. Fanboy here, spreading the word. Thanks!

title: idea: keep a list/wiki of elegant user-contributed 'oneliners'  for often occuring problems
"_.pluck" callback shorthand inconsistent with documentation
body:
http://lodash.com/docs#uniq

The `using "_.pluck" callback shorthand` example is not doing what the documentation says it will. Currently `_.pluck` returns an array with three items. The documentation shows it returning two. If it helps, it seems to work correctly when you pass an 'isSorted' value. 

This example would fail if it were a unit test.

``` js
_.uniq([{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }, { 'x': 1 }], 'x');  //  [{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }]

Actual result:
//  [{"x":1},{"x":2},{"x":1}]

When isSorted parameter is used it works
_.uniq([{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }, { 'x': 1 }], false, 'x'); //  [{"x":1},{"x":2}]
```

Is this a documentation or code issue? This is true for rc2 (which I use) and the lodash used on the documentation site (1.0.1)

As a side note, it might be useful if the example had different values for the unique parts of the subject. e.g. `_.uniq([{ 'x': 1 }, { 'x': 2 }, { 'x': 1, 'y': 5,  }], 'x')` I noticed that _.uniq (at least when using a callback) uses the first unique value in the result. This behavior isnt clear in the docs.

title: Feature Request: _.toLookup
flatten() with callback parameter
body:
If I have an array of objects that have array properties, I want to be able flatten the properties without creating an extra intermediary array.

For example:

``` js
var data = [ 
  { name: "a", stuff: [...] },
  { name: "b", stuff: [...] },
  { name: "c", stuff: [...] }
};

var allStuff = _(data).pluck('stuff').flatten();
```

Calling `pluck()` (or `map()` for more-complex scenarios) creates an extra array of arrays that I don't want.

Can you add a `flattenWith()` method (or just a `flatten(callback)`) method that does this all at once (and takes a callback or a property name)?

This would let me write

``` js
var allStuff = _.flattenWith(data, 'stuff');
```

(this is equivalent to C#'s [`SelectMany()`](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.linq.enumerable.selectmany.aspx))

title: _.first with callback broken, or documentation misleading
body:
Hey,

I've been using lodash and loving it, apart from one thing. Either `_.first`called with a callback is broken or the documentation is misleading/wrong.

Docs state: `If a callback function is passed, the first elements the callback returns truthy for are returned.`.

That's not what happens though. Here's [a jsFiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/Af7eN/2/) showing the problem. It seems like `_.first` always shortcuts out on the first falsy result.

title: find failing on docs page
Lo-Dash 1.0.0 is breaking Backbone's extend method
AMD and noConflict issue in compiled templates
body:
It appears that the output of the `_.template()` call includes a reference to a globally defined `_` for use in escaping parts of the template:

``` javascript
__e = _.escape,
```

As a result, these templates fail to run in a setup where `_` isn't available globally, which AMD discourages and `noConflict` does intentionally.

It seems that underscore.js doesn't include a reference to the `_.escape` function unless an escape pattern is matched.  However, it seems that lodash is always adding this reference:
https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L4728
I don't see a way to get it out of the lodash compiled templates so that they work without relying on global `_`.

Not sure what to do if someone specifically wants to use escaping.

Filed an issue over at the grunt-contrib-jst with regard to the same question, since the latest version over there recently switched from underscore to lodash:
https://github.com/gruntjs/grunt-contrib-jst/issues/18

title: Merge vs Extend object reference
body:
This might be by design.  Basically, when using merge, if the source object has a child object which does not exist in the destination object, the child object is recreated.  If you use extend, the child object is not recreated,

``` javascript
var foo = {x:1},
    merged = _.merge({}, {foo:foo}),
    extended = _.extend({}, {foo: foo});

console.log(merged.foo === foo); // false 
console.log(extended.foo === foo); // true
```

Wanted to point it out, in case it was not intentional.

title: _.merge behaves differently on nodejs & browser
body:
`_.merge` behaves behaves differently on nodejs & browser in regards to null overwriting.  

Specifically `_.merge({prop: "A String"}, {prop: null})` 
- on the browser (Firefox 18, Chrome 24) it gives `{prop:null}`. 
- on nodejs (0.8.12) it gives `{ prop: 'A String' }`

Using lodash 1.0.0-rc.3 on both environments (-min on the browser).

This might relate to #151, but the more serious question is **Should we generally expect  differing behaviours in different environments** ?

title: mapValues for objects
A check in _.isEqual for a custom equality function
No build option(s) to choose minification method?
body:
I apologize in advance if I'm being dense, but I've gone over the documentation and I'm having trouble reconciling the output I receive from the build script:

``` bash
% vendor/lodash/build.js                                                        
Downloading the Closure Compiler...
Downloading UglifyJS...
Compressing lodash.min using the Closure Compiler (simple)...
Done. Size: 7769 bytes.
Compressing lodash.min using the Closure Compiler (advanced)...
Done. Size: 7795 bytes.
Compressing lodash.min using UglifyJS...
Done. Size: 7815 bytes.
Compressing lodash.min using hybrid (simple)...
Done. Size: 7611 bytes.
Compressing lodash.min using hybrid (advanced)...
Done. Size: 7612 bytes.
```

Why does the build process need to download both Closure and Uglify? 

Why does it then need to _run_ both Closure and Uglify? 

Why can't I tell it to not download anything and just use the minifier I already have available on the machine responsible for doing the building? 

Why can't I tell it to not minify anything at all and let another script adopt that responsibility? 

This lack of control is making it difficult to integrate a lodash build into an existing application build process.

title: Template usage inconsistency when containing no evaluation blocks
body:
Hi bestiejs folk. Found an annoying issue that is partly my fault but and partly unexpected and unintuitive behavior in lodash.

Omitting `with` depending on whether or not there are evaluation blocks in the template can cause some confusing cases where a seemingly trivial change in a template can cause it to fail if accessing properties outside the context scope (doable in a `with` block, broken otherwise)

Relevant lines in lodash : https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/master/lodash.js#L4243-L4255

Given `window.foo = { val : "Bar" };`, the template

```
<% if (true) { %>Foo<% } %> <%= foo.val %>
```

Will output

```
Foo Bar
```

If you remove the the statement `<% if (true) { %>Foo<% } %>` the template breaks because it is no longer being compiled into a `with` block. The property `foo` is accessed off of the template variable (e.g. `obj.foo.val`) causing an error because `val` is being accessed off an undefined property.

[jsfiddle example](http://jsfiddle.net/WKSkS/2/)

Underscore build seems unaffected, but I'm running into this when using grunt-contrib-jst which uses lodash off of grunt.util._ so it's not as trivial as just swapping out lodash versions.

Probably worth documenting somewhere, if this is unlikely to change then I might put a footnote in contrib-jst.

Asking because inside the **"Chaining Methods"** section of the online doc (http://lodash.com/docs), it mentions:

> The chainable wrapper functions are:
> after, assign, bind, bindAll, bindKey, chain, compact, compose, concat, countBy, debounce, defaults, defer, delay, difference, filter, flatten, forEach, forIn, forOwn, functions, groupBy, initial, intersection, invert, invoke, keys, map, max, memoize, merge, min, object, omit, once, pairs, partial, pick, pluck, push, range, reject, rest, **_reverse_**, shuffle, slice, sort, sortBy, splice, tap, throttle, times, toArray, union, uniq, unshift, values, where, without, wrap, and zip

Though there doesn't seem to be such a method available at all.

Just a thought, but a few bytes per template could be saved by removing significant whitespace.
Could this be a command line flag while pre-compiling templates?

title: Add where-like support to analytic functions (every, some, find, etc)
body:
Hello,

It would be cool to execute the following code:

```
var joe = _.find(authors, { name : 'joe' });
var soldOutCompletly = _.every(books, { sold : true });
etc.
```

Thanks,
Alex

title: clone deep only goes 2 levels deep
body: after first recursive call deep is set false

title: TCO utility function
Chaining Documenation
body:
The documentation for "tap" has the example below.  It looks like it needs to be updated, as the "chain" function seems to have been replace with "_".  Also, the function parameters for "tap" seems to be different than the example.  I may be missing something there, though.

``` Javascript
_.chain([1, 2, 3, 200])
 .filter(function(num) { return num % 2 == 0; })
 .tap(alert)
 .map(function(num) { return num * num; })
 .value();
```

title: dropWhile and takeWhile
body:
Can you add support for these functions?

My needs are similar to the prelude-ls implementation:
http://gkz.github.com/prelude-ls/#f-takeWhile

`takeWhile`
Callable -> List -> List
Callable -> String -> String
Takes the first items of the list or string which pass the test.            

`dropWhile`
Callable -> List -> List
Callable -> String -> String
Drops the first items of the list or string which pass the test.

title: Add deep support to `_.defaults`.
body:
Hello!
I have some object with multiple nested object. For example, using the Mongoose ODM (and his method [populate](http://mongoosejs.com/docs/populate.html)), the NodeJS can return me an object Photo, in which the User object is embedded.
And I want to default Photo-object have a nested default User-object.

title: Merge on class properties changes parent class and derived classes
body:
Hi,

I tried to merge a config property of a derived class in CoffeeScript. It worked but it also did the change on the parent class and all other classes derived from it.

I prepared this fiddle to show it: http://jsfiddle.net/hijolan/9VeND/

There are two alerts. The second one should still show the string "bla"

Besides that: Thank you for that wonderfull library!!! :)

Best Regards, hijolan

title: _.merge assumes I don't want nulls copied.
body:
In my case, it assumes incorrectly:

`_.merge({ k1: 1, k2: 2 }, { k3: 3, k4: null })`

spits out:

`{ k1: 1, k2: 2, k3: 3 }`

when I need:

``{ k1: 1, k2: 2, k3: 3 , k4: null }`

exactly as I asked it for.

Null is not the same thing as undefined.

title: Template dependencies
body:
Given a template file, is there an easy way to grab the dependencies via lodash?

For instance, if I have `<%=name%>` somewhere in a file that I passed in, it would return 'name'?

(sorry I'm not putting this question in the right place, as it's not an issue but more of a question/feature-request from a newbie!)

title: Can't install module
body: http://pastebin.com/JMsQqX5f

title: Configure additional arguments for templates
_() chaining breaks when chained method returns empty array
body:
Using `_.chain()`:

`_.chain([1]).initial() // returns a wrapped empty array`

When using `_(...)`:

`_([1]).initial() // returns empty array`

This is problematic because often times I find myself keeping an array of objects and later applying `.invoke()` on it after running `.initial()` or `.rest()`. Since the new form returns an empty array, I get a `TypeError: Object [object Array] has no method 'invoke'` instead of it just being a noop as has become expected.

title: Please consider adding an 'extract' method for nested objects
_.max return value is wrong / incompatibility with Underscore.js
body:
underscore: 
_([]).max(..) === undefined
... which I'd consider as being correct

lodash:
_([]).max(..) === -Infinity
... which I'd consider as being wrong

title: Special version of isEqual to compare objects.
body:
I've just looked through `_.isEqual` source code and discovered that it is real all-embracing function, but also real rich. My practice shows that mostly often purpose to use this function is to compare two objects (possibly, but not, compulsory, they are have nested objects to compare too). In any other ways I usually know how to use vanilla JS techniques of comparing.

So, I consider function that do such stuff, leaving all other comparsions: numbers, `null`s, `NaN`s, `undefined` etc, replacing them only with strict comparsion.

.1 No nested objects:
First of all I tried to express this function in other LoDash/Underscore standard functions and I discover combination of two difference `( !_.difference(a, b).length && !_.difference(b, a).length)`. In words "no difference between to objects".

In one subsidiary module I've implemented [such stuff](https://github.com/StreetStrider/utils/blob/master/tests/options/options.js#L6). This is realisation of difference idea, but without high-level _.difference operation.

.2 Nested objects:
I think this case is also important for object comparsion and `_.isEqual` is really good. Mostly sad that `_.isEqual` do many side operations that I do not need in object comparsion.

Sorry if this topic is duplicate, I've looked through issues but did't find anything similar.

title: Differences between merge and extend/assign is unclear and confusing
body:
I'm seeing the following differences between assign and merge:

```
_.assign({foo:"bar"}, {foo:null})
// result {foo:null}

_.merge({foo:"bar"}, {foo:null})
// result {foo:"bar"}
```

Merge appears to not overwrite on null but assign does. Is this expected? It's not at all clear to me from the docs.

merge:

> Merges enumerable properties of the source object(s) into the destination object. Subsequent sources will overwrite propery assignments of previous sources.

assign:

> Assigns own enumerable properties of source object(s) to the destination object. Subsequent sources will overwrite propery assignments of previous sources.

From the docs it appears that the only differences between these two should be a `hasOwnProperty` check. If that's the case, then the issue I'm experiencing is a bug. If this difference is expected, it would be great if it were mentioned in the API docs.

Thanks and keep up the great work on this project!

title: add `at` method to use an array to get elements from a collection
Tweak `-0` and `0` behavior in `_.isEqual`
body: Do you all think we should relax `_.isEqual`'s rules for `0` and `-0`, if two `NaN` values and `3` and `Object(3)` are considered equal then should `-0` and `0` be considered equal as well.

title: add `_.deepClone` (alias for `_.clone(obj, true)` )
body:
I caught a number of bugs in my code this morning that were the result of using shallow clone rather than deep clone. In fixing these, I made an alias called `_.deepClone` to improve code readability. 

Since the second parameter in `_.clone` is just a flag to determine this behavior, I wanted to get your thoughts on moving this behavior to a proper method to make code more self-documenting (and thus more maintainable).

title: Lodash >=0.9.2 fails to install on 64-bit Windows 7 (standard user account)
body:
There's a couple packages with a dependency on lodash 0.9.2 (most notably grunt 0.4) that fails to install on 64-bit Windows 7 when running a regular user account (this is on an university computer - Node.js is installed properly and works just fine). Lodash 0.8.2 installed just fine, but 1.0.0 RCs also have this same installation issue.

```
210 info install lodash@0.9.2
211 verbose unsafe-perm in lifecycle true
212 silly exec cmd "/c" "node build/post-install"
213 silly cmd,/c,node build/post-install,C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\GitHub\ExLinks\node_modules\lodash spawning
214 info lodash@0.9.2 Failed to exec install script
215 info C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\GitHub\ExLinks\node_modules\lodash unbuild
216 verbose from cache C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\GitHub\ExLinks\node_modules\lodash\package.json
217 info preuninstall lodash@0.9.2
218 info uninstall lodash@0.9.2
219 verbose true,C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\GitHub\ExLinks\node_modules,C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\GitHub\ExLinks\node_modules unbuild lodash@0.9.2
220 verbose C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\GitHub\ExLinks\node_modules\.bin,[object Object] binRoot
221 info postuninstall lodash@0.9.2
222 error lodash@0.9.2 install: `node build/post-install`
222 error `cmd "/c" "node build/post-install"` failed with 127
223 error Failed at the lodash@0.9.2 install script.
223 error This is most likely a problem with the lodash package,
223 error not with npm itself.
223 error Tell the author that this fails on your system:
223 error     node build/post-install
223 error You can get their info via:
223 error     npm owner ls lodash
223 error There is likely additional logging output above.
224 error System Windows_NT 6.1.7601
225 error command "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\\\node.exe" "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "install" "lodash@0.9.2"
227 error node -v v0.8.15
228 error npm -v 1.1.66
229 error code ELIFECYCLE
230 verbose exit [ 1, true ]
```

It seems to fail when it comes to getting for the [Closure Compiler and UglifyJS](https://github.com/bestiejs/lodash/blob/master/build/post-install.js#L127) (based on the "failed with 127"), and I can't figure out how I could make this work (especially when it's installed as a dependency by another package and makes the installation fail because of it).

title: Add "@license" to copyright header block
body:
This adds the JSDoc `@license` to ensure that the comment block is not removed by Closure Compiler, if Lo-Dash is being included as part of another library.

I'm not sure under what condition the "underscore" template is used, I was not able to reproduce it's use, and thus I left it alone.

I'm not sure if this is something you'll rather have as an option to lodash, but this is what I was thinking for the output.

title: Please consider supporting _.isDefined
body:
I know it can be done by:

```
if( ! _.isUndefined(obj.key) ){ }
```

but sometimes it is confusing and takes a few mental cycles to parse the code while it is straightforward and easy to read:

```
if( _.isDefined(obj.key) ){ }
```

title: Test on PhantomJS
body: PhantomJS did not seem to be in the list of javascript engines that lodash has been tested against, but it would be wonderful if it were.

title: deep extend
body:
Shameless plug:

I've turned Kurt Milam's _.deepExtend mixin into a npm package.

https://github.com/pygy/undescoreDeepExtend/

It works with any library that implements underscore's API, basically underscore itself and lodash ATM. Dependency injection FTW!

title: _.chain(foo).bind(...) returns the foo rather than the chainable value
body:
The following code differs from Underscore.js.

``` javascript
function foo() {}

_.chain(foo).bind({})
```

Underscore.js returns a chainable, wrapped instance of foo. In Lodash, a bound version of `foo()` is returned and is no longer chainable.

I've only had the time to test this on Firefox 17, but presumably this would be the case on any Javascript engine that implements a native version of Function#bind.

title: Object-oriented and functional styles return different results
body:
This returns the correct grouped object

``` javascript
_.groupBy([4.2, 6.1, 6.4], function(num) { return Math.floor(num); });
```

This returns the lodash object with a **wrapped** method containing the results

``` javascript
_([4.2, 6.1, 6.4]).groupBy(function(num) { return Math.floor(num); });
```

title: Timer drift bug in throttle
body: The remaining <= 0 case does not set timeoutId to null, so it is possible for throttle to drop calls and stop setting new timeouts entirely if it gets just the right call timings.  Setting timeoutId to null after the clearTimeout call fixes this.

title: Chaining _.range() ignores start/end
body:
Not sure if this is a bug or expected behavior.

_.chain().range(1, 10) ignores the 2nd parameter and returns a wrapped array containing just 0

http://jsfiddle.net/dpSsp/
